lines.text: When in Baghdad, do as Baghdaddies do!
Mr. Bonaparte won't be using his telephone today.
The little devil promised to call!
Don't cry over spilt milk. There's enough water in it already.
Don't say ain't.
I've said ain't for twenty-five years.
That ain't so!
It's a good thing it rains, or else there'd be no hay to make when the sun shines.
Many a live wire would go dead if it weren't for his connections.

[Pretending to be a waiter, offering an appetizer to Ma Harrington]
Noiseless celery from contented farms?
Stupid! How do you feel now?

[Pretending to be off her rocker in order to gain Ma's symphathy]
You know how you feel when you don't know how you feel? That's how I feel.

[Persuading Billy to leave with Grace]
You've got your honey - now buzz!

[Summing up her side of an argument regarding whether she should have been alone with Billy Caldwell]
I don't give a whoopin' darn!
Pat, I want you to stop hanging around when Tony calls on Grace. You just moon around.
I don't moon. Do I moon, Pa?
My neck hurts. I think I've dislocated my vertebrae again.
Never mind the symptoms - - you can have the couch. Maybe you don't believe it, but I've had a pain the neck ever since we married.
Your ma has her good points, Pat.
She sure has. They stick out all over her.
Seems like ma's tears is the greatest water power on earth.
Star light, star bright; First star I've seen tonight. Wish I may, wish I might, Have the wish I wish tonight.
What did you wish, Baby?
I wish I were beautiful and seductive.
You are, Baby - - you're marvelous.
You think so, Pop, but nobody else does. I'd like to be entrancing, alluring, ravishing - like a stocking advertisement.
The Yacht Club - where if Mary had a little lamb it would cost $4.50 per order.
Don't you know it's bad manners to be polite to a waiter?
Doesn't that music go right to your feet?
Always remember - Nature gives us many of our features, but she lets us pick our own teeth.
No thank you, Mr. Smith - work is the curse of our drinking classes.
No wonder a hen gets discouraged. She can never find things where she lays them.
Let ma keep on thinking you're a bit cuckoo and you can do anything you want to.
Ma, what is a hot dog?
I don't know, darling. What is a hot dog?
A hamburger in tights.
You're not crazy - you just haven't any brains.
Where's Grace?
She went out, but I'm sure she'll be right back. Please wait.
I'm through! She can't make a sap out of me!
All the world's a stage, but most of us are only stage hands.
I came here to see Grace because I want a woman's viewpoint on these plans.
I'm a woman - and I'm just full of viewpoints.
That's right - I hadn't thought of it.
I saw the slickest movie last night and the girl in it sure knew her onions.
I found her in Billy Caldwell's house - and they were both drunk.
If it wasn't for you our family tree would die.
What do you mean by that?
You're the sap.
Shut your big mouth.
That's no keyhole in the front of your face.
For twenty-five years you've been whining and nagging and bawling and making everybody's life miserable...
But, Pop, I do love ma.
So do I, dammit.
I'll sit down - - but I won't stand for anything.
Where's Pat?
Upstairs moping around...
